Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Atom Interferometry Experiments in Fundamental Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Research supported by this CAREER award is exploring new ways to use atom interferometry to perform precision tests of fundamental laws of physics. An atom interferometer uses the wave-particle duality of quantum mechanics. An atomic (e.g., cesium) matter wave is split and sent along two paths. When the two waves are interfered, the probability of detecting the atom is given by the phase difference of the matter waves. The high sensitivity of atom interferometers derives from the fact that the phase difference can be millions of radians, whereas tiny fractions of radians lead to a measurable change in the detection probability. The instruments being constructed for this research use cesium and lithium atoms. They use "large momentum transfer," a new method that allows attaining a large separation of the matter wave's paths, thus increasing sensitivity. This method is further improved as part of this research.

The instruments are applied to pursue an exciting research agenda in fundamental physics: Measuring a fundamental constant that characterizes the strength of the electromagnetic interaction, known as the fine structure constant, and thereby testing the theory of quantum electrodynamics to high precision; testing the notion that the force of gravitation must obey the laws of Einstein's theory of General Relativity, such as the fact that gravity knows no preferred direction; and testing the universality of free fall, one of the fundamental ingredients of the Einstein Equivalence Principle, from which all of General Relativity follows. Undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs take part, so this research helps training the next generation of scientists and engineers. The PI has noted that deep involvement in research often starts at a rather late stage of the student's career. The PI therefore seeks to increase the participation of undergraduate students, and in fact one of the interferometers used for this research has been set up mainly by an undergraduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

This project has produced two main types of results

1. Lithium interferometry: We have developed interferometry with laser-cooled lithium atoms at a temperature of 300 µK (50Tr). The relatively large thermal velocity of lithium atoms at such temperatures was mitigated by newly developed technology. Fast laser pulses are used to interact with atoms regardless of their velocity. Running two interferometers at the same time relaxes requirements on velocity selection further. Our results relax cooling requirements for atom interferometry, allowing for increased precision through high experimental repetition rates. Extending these techniques would allow for recoil-sensitive interferometry with atoms and other particles, such as electrons.

2. Measuring the fine structure constant. Measurements of the fine-structure constant α are powerful tests of the overall consistency of theory and experiment across physics, having used methods from atomic, condensed-matter, and particle physics. We have measured it at 2.0×10-10 accuracy, via the recoil frequency of cesium-133 atoms in a matter-wave interferometer. Multiphoton interactions such as Bragg diffraction and Bloch oscillations yield both unparalleled overall phase difference for the interferometer of over 12 million radians, and control of systematic effects at the 0.12 ppb level. Our measurement is an unprecedented test of the standard model of particle physics: for the first time, a direct measurement of α has an error below the 5th order quantum electrodynamics contribution in the electron’s gyromagnetic anomaly, allowing us to probe that term. Our measurement also has implications for the unexplained anomaly of the muon’s magnetic moment, and strongly constrains multiple dark sector candidates as well as a possible electron substructure.

Broader impact

Our theory work on the equivalence principle and atom interferometry is responsible for more than 1/3 of the known limits on equivalence principle violations in the Standard Model Extension. Other experimental groups are using our analysis as a basis for their experiments. After initial discussion, the interpretation of a quantum phase as gravitational time dilation has become the basis for a large amount of independent research, e.g. on decoherence. 

Compton-frequency measurements of masses with atom interferometry are interesting for the re-definition of the kilogram. 

The project helped to launch the independent careers of several young scientists. Numerous undergraduate students working on this project went on to graduate school at, e.g., at Harvard, Max-Planck (Munich), MIT, Rochester, and Yale. One former graduate student (Geena Kim) has just accepted her assistant professor position in computer science at Regis University (Denver, CO). The postdocs have launched independent careers: Shau-Yu Lan, is assistant professor of physics at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore. Michael Hohensee is a staff scientist at Lawrence Livermore National Lab.  Paul Hamilton has earned an Assistant Professor of Physics position at UCLA. 

Our group is actively involved in involving members of underrepresented minorities (URM) in reserach, e.g., by participation in initiatives UC Berkeley initiatives suach as COMPASS which have a focus on underrepresented students. The PI incolves undergraduates from Cal State East Bay in his reserach group, one of the Nation's most diverse schools by several quantitative measures. Two of them have become UC Berkeley graduate students, and one of them won an NSF graduate fellowship.
